**The *Zhong Lü Transmission of the Dao* (18 scrolls)**
*Inscribed by the True Person of Zhengyang, Zhongli Quan, recounting the Pure Yang True Person Lü Dongbin’s (Master Hongjun) teachings, transmitted by the True Person of Huayang, Shi Jianwu (Master Xisheng).*
*Composed entirely in question-and-answer form.*

**Discourse on True Immortals (First)**
Lü said: *"When a person is born—secure yet free of illness, vigorous yet free of aging, alive yet free of death—what Dao can achieve this?"*

Zhong replied: *"A person’s birth begins when the two *qi* of father and mother converge, their essence and blood forming the embryo. After the Primordial Beginning (*Taichu*), the primordial substance (*taizhi*) takes form. Yin sustains yang’s generation; *qi* follows the embryo’s transformation, and after three hundred days, the form is complete. The luminous spirit enters the body, separating from the mother. From the Primordial Substance onward, the *qi* ascends and descends, nurturing the yellow sprout. At five thousand days, the *qi* is full, its measure reaching eighty-one *zhang*. At fifteen, one is called a ‘boy’—when yin contains half of yang, like the light of the rising sun. Beyond this point, the primordial yang scatters, true *qi* dissipates, and weakness brings illness, aging, death, and extinction. A lifetime of ignorance damages the luminous spirit; a lifetime of folly depletes one’s allotted years. Thus, birth and death differ in rank, and lifespans vary in length. Born, then annihilated; annihilated, then reborn—cycle after cycle, unaware, one falls into other realms, losing one’s true form to alien shells. The root of true nature is lost to humanity, trapped in samsaric revolutions with no escape. Only if one encounters a True Immortal or Perfected Sage can one’s sins be purged, the old skin shed, and a human form regained. Yet even then, lingering in stupidity and illness, one accumulates karmic debts across lifetimes, ascending to blessed lands only to still suffer hunger, cold, and calamity. Through gradual refinement, one may attain a complete form—but remains bound to servitude and lowly stations. Should one repeat past transgressions, like a ball rolling off a board, one returns to samsaric cycles."*

Lü said: *"Born in the Central Realm, fortunate to live in peace, with food and time not yet scarce—those who love are at ease, those who resent fall ill, the greedy live on, the fearful perish. Today, I kneel before my revered teacher, twice bowing, twice pleading: given that birth and death are paramount, may I humbly beg for instruction on the principles of avoiding illness, aging, and death, and be guided by my teacher?"*

Zhong replied: *"To escape samsara, avoid alien forms, and ensure a body free of illness, aging, death, and suffering—standing firm beneath heaven, embracing yin and cradling yang as a true human—this is the path. Among humans, some refine to become immortals; among immortals, some ascend to heaven."*

Lü said: *"The dead become ghosts; those who attain the Dao become immortals. If immortals are of one rank, why speak of ascending from immortality to heaven?"*

Zhong replied: *"Immortals are not one. Pure yin without yang is a ghost; pure yang without yin is an immortal; a mix of yin and yang is a human. Only humans can become ghosts or immortals. Youth who do not cultivate, indulging in licentiousness, die and become ghosts. Those who awaken and refine transcend humanity, shedding their form to become immortals. There are five ranks of immortals and three stages of attainment. Cultivation lies with the practitioner, and fulfillment follows one’s capacity."*

Lü said: *"You speak of three stages of attainment and five ranks of immortals—why?"*

Zhong replied: *"The three stages are lesser, middle, and greater attainment. The five ranks are: ghost-immortals, human-immortals, earth-immortals, spirit-immortals, and heavenly-immortals—all are immortals. Ghost-immortals remain bound to ghosts; human-immortals to humanity; earth-immortals to the earth; spirit-immortals to the spirit realm; heavenly-immortals to heaven."*

Lü said: *"What are these ‘ghost-immortals’?"*

Zhong replied: *"The lowest of the five immortals. Though they escape the yin realm, their divine forms are unclear, their ghostly essence nameless in the Three Mountains, their names unknown in Penglai. Though they avoid rebirth, they cannot return to the immortal lands. They have no true abode, only the chance to be reborn into another form."*

Lü said: *"Then these ‘ghost-immortals’—what methods do they practice, what efforts do they expend to attain such a state?"*

Zhong replied: *"Those who cultivate, at first, do not grasp the Great Dao, yet seek swift attainment. Their bodies are like gnarled wood, their minds like dead ashes, their spirit and consciousness held inward, their resolve unshaken. Within meditation, they emerge with a yin-born spirit—thus a pure and luminous ghost, not a true Daoist immortal. Since their single resolve does not scatter and their yin-essence lingers, they are called ‘ghost-immortals.’ Though called immortals, they are truly ghosts. The ancients and modern adherents of the *Chóngshì* sect, when their efforts reach this point, claim they have attained the Dao—how laughable!"*

Lü said: *"Then what are these ‘human-immortals’?"*

Zhong replied: *"Human-immortals are the second lowest of the five. Cultivators of the True Dao, though they grasp neither the Great Dao nor its methods, fix their resolve and labor tirelessly throughout their lives. The Five *Xíng* qi are wrongly mingled, their forms and essences hardened—thus the Eight *Yī* evils cannot harm them. They live long and suffer little, and so are called ‘human-immortals.’"*

Lü said: *"Then these ‘human-immortals’—what methods, what efforts lead to such a state?"*

Zhong replied: *"Those who cultivate, at first, may hear of the Great Dao. Yet their karmic burdens are heavy and their blessings thin; all manner of trials cause them to abandon their original resolve, settling for minor achievements. They claim their methods have merit, yet their resolve never shifts nor their practices change with the seasons. Like those who forsake the Five Flavors, how could they know of the Six *Qì*? Those who forget the Seven Emotions, how could they grasp the Ten *Jiè*? Those who practice *Shùyǎn* spitting, yet take breath in wrongly. Those who wear *Cǎibǔ* patches, yet mock *Qīngjìng* purity as foolishness. Those who greedily seize external *qi* to cheat Heaven and Earth, yet refuse to abstain from food. Those who cling to visualization, yet neglect *Dǎoyǐn* exercises. Alone they sit, breath confined—how could they know of *Zìrán*? They strain their bodies, yet fail to recognize *Wúwéi*. They draw yin-qi from women, differing not from those who shrink the Golden Tortoise. They nourish yang with girl’s milk, differing not from those who refine elixirs. By such analogies, one could enumerate their errors endlessly. Yet all these are still Dao, though they cannot fulfill the Great Dao. They merely achieve minor comforts, longevity, and ease within one method or technique—thus they are called ‘human-immortals.’ And there are many more in the world who, delighting in fleeting gains yet weary of sustained effort, practice carelessly, misjudging times and days, and instead bring on sickness while failing to extend their years."*

Lü said: *"Then what are these ‘earth-immortals’?"*

Zhong replied: *"Earth-immortals are the midpoint between mortal and Daoist, possessing the potential of spirit-immortals. They do not grasp the Great Dao, yet attain minor achievements. Their efforts are unseen, but they linger long in the world, never dying among humanity."*

Lü said: *"How does one begin the practice of ‘earth-immortals’?"*

Zhong replied: *"First, one must follow the Dao of Heaven and Earth’s ascent and descent, and take the numbers of the Sun and Moon’s generation and growth. Within the body, one applies the cycles of years and months; within the day, one applies the moments of time. First, one must recognize the **Dragon** and **Tiger** [1], then align the **Kàn** and **Lí** [2]. One distinguishes the purity and turbidity of water, and divides the **qi** and climate into early and late. One gathers the **Zhēn Yī** [True Unity/essence and breath], observes the **Èr Yī** [Two Principles/yang and yin], arranges the **Sān Cái** [Three Talents/Heaven, Earth, and humanity], divides the **Sì Xiàng** [Four Symbols/Four Celestial Animals], separates the **Wǔ Yùn** [Five Phases], stabilizes the **Liù Qì** [Six Qi], collects the **Qí Bǎo** [Seven Treasures], sequences the **Bā Guà** [Eight Trigrams], and traverses the **Jiǔ Zhōu** [Nine Continents]. When the Five Phases are inverted, the **qi** flows to the **mother phase** while the **liquid essence** circulates between the **father and mother phases** [3]. The **Three Fields** [4] are reversed in repetition, refining into elixirs. One permanently subdues the lower field, refines the form to dwell in the world, and thus attains immortality—this is called ‘earth-immortal.’"*

Lü said: *"What are these ‘spirit-immortals’?"*

Zhong replied: *"Spirit-immortals are those who, having grown weary of earthly residence as earth-immortals, yet persist in their practice without ceasing. When their joints are harmonized, they extract lead and add mercury, refining the **golden essence** to the vertex. The **jade liquid** returns to the elixir field, where the formed **qi** aligns with the Five Qi toward the **primordial source** [5], and the Three Yangs gather at the crown. When their practice is complete, they forget their form, and the **embryonic immortal** transforms naturally. With yin exhausted and yang pure, they attain a body beyond the body. Abandoning their physical substance, they ascend as immortals, transcending the mundane to become **sages**. They reject worldly affairs and return to the **Three Mountains** [6], thus they are called ‘spirit-immortals.’"*

Lü said: *"What then are these ‘heaven-immortals’?"*

Zhong replied: *"Earth-immortals who grow weary of the Three Mountains and instead transmit the Dao to the world—where their practice yields results and their deeds are manifest—when both are fulfilled, they receive the **Heavenly Scripture** and return to the **Cave of Heaven** [7], and this is called ‘heaven-immortal.’ If they then grow weary of the Cave of Heaven and take up official duties as immortal officials, they are called: the lower **Water Official**, the middle **Earth Official**, and the upper **Heaven Official**. Their contributions to Heaven and Earth are vast, and their deeds in the present and past are profound. Ascending through official ranks, they traverse the **Thirty-Six Caves of Heaven** and return to the **Eighty-One Yang Skies** [8], ultimately ascending to the realm of the **Three Pure Ones** [9] in **Natural Emptiness** [10]."*

Lü said: *"‘Ghost-immortals’ are indeed unattainable, and ‘heaven-immortals’ are beyond my daring to aspire to. May I inquire now: are the methods of ‘human-immortals,’ ‘earth-immortals,’ and ‘spirit-immortals’ accessible in this age?"*

Zhong replied: *"Human-immortals do not exceed the minor achievements, earth-immortals do not exceed the intermediate achievements, and spirit-immortals do not exceed the great achievements. These three grades are, in essence, one. To seek the Dao through methods, the Dao is not difficult. To seek immortality through the Dao, immortality is also quite easy."*

Lü said: *"In ancient and modern times, those who cultivated life have not failed to seek longevity, nor failed to seek ascension as immortals. Yet still, they do not attain longevity or ascension. Why is this?"*

Zhong replied: *"Their methods do not align with the Dao. Through excessive knowledge and forced comprehension, they generate minor techniques and tangential paths, which do not escape sickness and death—though they may still be called **corpse dissolution** [11]. They deceive the world, promoting one another, and thus lead others astray from the Great Dao. Even those with sincere faith and resolute will, who have practiced diligently for long, ultimately see no results and pass away in their appointed time. Alas!"*

**《Zhōng Lǚ Chuándào Jí》 – On the Great Dao (Section II)**

Lǚ said: *"What is meant by the **Great Dao**?"*

Zhōng replied: *"The Great Dao is formless, nameless, unquestioned, and unanswered. Its vastness knows no outer limit, its subtlety knows no inner bound. It cannot be known, nor can it be practiced!"*

Lǚ said: *"In ancient and modern times, those who attained the Dao began by studying it, then by possessing it, then by embodying it, and finally by perfecting it—thus ascending from the mundane world to Penglai, to the Cavernous Heavens, to the Yang Heaven, and ultimately to the Three Pure Ones. Yet today, the Master alone declares that the Dao cannot be known or practiced. But in the Dao, is he not secretly attaining something?"*

Zhōng replied: *"I have no hidden attainment in the Dao. Truly, all who claim to follow the Dao possess only its name. Though they hear of the Great Dao, they lack faith; though they have faith, they lack resolve. They begin with diligence and end in neglect, sitting and forgetting to rise, standing and forgetting to act. They begin with anxiety and toil, yet conclude in sloth. Because of this, I say the Great Dao is difficult to know and difficult to practice."*

「Lǚ asked: *"How does the principle of the Great Dao being difficult to know and difficult to practice manifest?"*

Zhōng replied: *"Through minor practices of peripheral schools, one can easily see results, yet people still desire to attain many benefits. They teach one another these methods, yet to their deaths, they fail to awaken. Thus, they become customs, corrupting and undermining the Great Dao. There are those who observe fasts and abstain from grains, those who gather qi, those who rinse and gargle, those who abandon their wives, those who cut off flavors, those who practice meditation and dhyāna, those who remain silent, those who cultivate visualization, those who gather yin, those who ingest breath, those who uphold purity, those who still the mind, those who sever attachments, those who open the crown, those who withdraw into the tortoise shell, those who cut off traces, those who chant scriptures, those who refine through burning, those who regulate breath, those who guide and pull [the body], those who exhale and inhale, those who gather and supplement, those who give alms, those who provide offerings, those who rescue and relieve, those who enter mountains, those who recognize nature, those who remain unmoved, those who uphold teachings—...the minor practices of peripheral schools cannot all be listed.

As for methods like gathering the radiance of the sun and moon, cultivating the qi of heaven and earth, concentrating thought and intention to form elixir and cinnabar, straining the body to seek transcendence, where one enters more than one exits, and where one may even attack illnesses—these are acceptable for nurturing the true essence. To believe in the prenatal breath, sever all thoughts and forget speech, these are acceptable for nurturing one’s nature. To consider oneself as the *Tài Yī* containing the true qi, achieving the *Jīn Qiāng Bù Dǎo* [immovable golden spear], making the Yellow River flow backward—these are inferior methods for prolonging life.

The body may wither like dry wood, the mind grow cold as dead ashes, these mere tricks of gathering spirit. Yet why do ancient and modern practitioners of the Dao, who toil and strain with their hearts, so often cling to these petty concerns?"」

How can swallowing saliva as medicine bring about transformation?
How can gathering *qi* as elixir achieve permanence?
To take the liver as the Dragon and the lungs as the Tiger—how can this bring union?
To regard *Kàn* as lead and *Lí* as mercury—how can this allow for extraction and supplementation?
To water the seasons in hope of sprouting the Yellow Sprout,
To focus the mind unscattered in pursuit of the Great Medicine—
Yet misaligning years and months, wasting days and disrupting times,
Unknowing the roots of the Five Phases—how can one grasp the *Sān Cái*’s transformation?
To pluck branches and leaves, only to mislead later generations—
Thus the Dao grows ever more distant, ever more estranged,
Heterodoxies arise as custom, betraying the Master’s original intent.
All from hearsay and oral tradition,
Passing secrets to the unknowing, teaching by rote,
Following sequences into the underworld—chilling the heart.
It is not that one does not wish to expound the Great Dao—
Rather, the world’s sins are heavy, blessings meager,
They do not trust Heaven’s workings, value wealth over life,
And willingly become ghosts.

Lü said: *“Having known the petty methods and side paths,
May I hear of the Great Dao?”*

Zhōng said: *“The Dao has no questions, questions have no answers.
Yet when the true essence is once divided, the Primordial Simplicity has already scattered.
The Dao generates One, One generates Two, Two generates Three.
One is the essence, Two is the function, Three is transformation.
Essence and function do not depart from yin and yang,
Transformation arises from their union.
Above, middle, and below form the Three *Cái*;
Heaven, Earth, and Human share in the Dao.
The Dao generates the Two *Qì*, *qi* generates the Three *Cái*,
The Three *Cái* generate the Five Phases, the Five Phases generate all things.
Among all things, the most refined, most noble—is Humanity.
Only Humanity exhausts the principles of all things,
Fulfills its own nature.
To exhaust principles and fulfill nature is to reach life—
To preserve life and safeguard existence is to align with the Dao,
Thus one should match Heaven and Earth in endurance,
And share in their eternal duration.”*

Lü said: *“Long-lasting and enduring, spanning millennia without end.
Human life is but a hundred years, seventy being rare.
Why does the Dao belong uniquely to Heaven and Earth, distant from humanity?”*

Zhōng said: *“The Dao is not distant from humanity—humanity distances itself from the Dao.
The reason for this distance is ignorance of the methods to nurture life.
The reason for ignorance is not recognizing the proper timing of effort.
The reason for failing to recognize timing is not comprehending Heaven and Earth’s mechanisms.”*

**Discussion on Heaven and Earth (Section Three)**

Lü said: *“What of Heaven and Earth’s mechanisms—may they be heard?”*

Zhōng said: *“Heaven and Earth’s mechanisms are the Dao’s great operation, whereby yin and yang ascend and descend without ceasing, upholding and sustaining themselves to attain enduring firmness. They have never lightly revealed themselves to humankind.”*

Lü said: *“How does Heaven and Earth’s adherence to the Dao manifest as a sustaining mechanism? How does this operation begin? How does its efficacy become apparent?”*

Zhōng said: *“Once the great Dao manifests as form, it gives rise to numbers. Heaven obtains the *Qián* Dao, taking *one* as its essence—light and pure, dwelling above—its function being *yang*. Earth obtains the *Kūn* Dao, taking *two* as its essence—heavy and turbid, dwelling below—its function being *yin*. As *yang* ascends and *yin* descends, they mutually intermingle. The operations of *Qián* and *Kūn* never stray from the Dao, and their beginnings have their season, their efficacy its appointed day.”*

Lü said: *“Heaven, obtaining the *Qián* Dao, functions through *yang*—*yang* governs ascent, so how does it interact with Earth? Earth, obtaining the *Kūn* Dao, functions through *yin*—*yin* governs descent, so how does it interact with Heaven? If Heaven and Earth do not interact, how can *yin* and *yang* unite? If *yin* and *yang* do not unite, how can *Qián* and *Kūn* operate? If *Qián* and *Kūn* have no operation, though there be beginnings and days of efficacy, how can the great Dao be attained?”*

Zhōng said: *“Heaven’s Dao takes *Qián* as its essence, *yang* as its function, and accumulates *qi* above. Earth’s Dao takes *Kūn* as its essence, *yin* as its function, and accumulates water below. Heaven, in its Dao, uses *Qián* to probe *Kūn*. The first probing yields the eldest son—*Zhèn*. The second probing yields the middle son—*Kàn*. The third probing yields the youngest son—*Gèn*. Thus, Heaven interacts with Earth, using the *Qián* Dao to probe the *Kūn* Dao and generate the three *yang*s.

When Earth, in its Dao, uses *Kūn* to probe *Qián*, the first probing yields the eldest daughter—*Xùn*. The second probing yields the middle daughter—*Lí*. The third probing yields the youngest daughter—*Duì*. Thus, Earth interacts with Heaven, using the *Kūn* Dao to probe the *Qián* Dao and generate the three *yin*s. The three *yang*s unite with the three *yin*s, and all things are born. The three *yin*s unite with the three *yang*s, and all things are completed. Heaven and Earth’s union originates from *Qián* and *Kūn* probing each other and moving within the Dao. *Qián* and *Kūn* probing each other generate the six *qi*; the six *qi* intermingling differentiate the five phases; the five phases intermingling give rise to all things.

When the *Qián* Dao descends, the three probings completed, the *yang* ascends anew—*yang* within concealing *yin*, returning to Heaven. When the *Kūn* Dao ascends, the three probings completed, the *yin* descends anew—*yin* within concealing *yang*, returning to Earth. *Yang* concealing *yin*, the *yin* does not dissipate—this is called *true yin*. *True yin* reaches Heaven, born through *yang*, hence *yin* descends from Heaven—how could *yin* within lack *yang*? *Yin* concealing *yang*, the *yang* does not perish—this is called *true yang*. *True yang* reaches Earth, born through *yin*, hence *yang* ascends from Earth—how could *yang* within lack *yin*? *Yang* concealing *yin* returns to Earth; *yin* concealing *yang* returns to Heaven. Thus, it cycles endlessly without cessation. Their union never strays from the Dao—that is how they attain enduring firmness.”*

Lü said: *“Heaven and Earth’s mechanisms, moving within the Dao to attain enduring firmness, are the operations of Heaven and Earth. Yet humanity, though endowed with wisdom, attends to purity of mind. Seeking to practice the great Dao—whether to secure minor comfort and longevity, moderate immortality, or supreme transcendence—how should one operate and move within the Dao, activating Heaven’s mechanisms, to also attain enduring firmness and eternal preservation?”*

Zhōng said: *“The great Dao is formless; it takes form through what it obtains. The great Dao is nameless; it takes names through what it possesses. Heaven and Earth obtain it, and it is called the *Qián-Kūn* Dao. The sun and moon obtain it, and it is called the *yin* and *yang* Dao. If humanity obtains it, in the court it is called the Dao of *junzi* and ministers; in the inner chambers, the Dao of husband and wife; in the village, the Dao of elders and juniors; in the schools, the Dao of friends; in the home, the Dao of father and son. Thus, all outward manifestations are governed by the Dao.

As for parents’ union: the father’s *yang* advances first, followed by *yin*, true *qi* meeting true water—heart-fire and kidney-water intermingling, refined into essence. Once essence emerges, the mother’s *yin* advances first, her water cleansing what is useless. Then the mother’s *yang* advances, her blood receiving at the palace’s gate. Essence and blood form the embryo, containing true *qi* within the mother’s womb. Over days and months, true *qi* transforms and gives birth to humanity, as Heaven and Earth move in their Dao—*Qián* and *Kūn* probing each other—generating the three *ming* and three *yang*s.

True *qi* is *yang*; true water is *yin*. *Yang* is concealed within water; *yin* is concealed within *qi*. *Qi* governs ascent, yet within it lies true water. Water governs descent, yet within it lies true *qi*. True water is *true yin*; true *qi* is *true yang*. *True yang* descends with water, as *Qián* probes *Kūn*—above is *Zhèn*, middle is *Kàn*, below is *Gèn*. Compared to humanity, taking the center as measure, from above to below: *Zhèn* is the liver, *Kàn* the kidneys, *Gèn* the bladder.

*True yin* ascends with *qi*, as *Kūn* probes *Qián*—below is *Xùn*, middle is *Lí*, above is *Duì*.”*

「When comparing to humanity, taking the center as measure, from below to above: *Xùn* is the gallbladder, *Lí* the heart, *Duì* the lungs.

Once the forms are complete and the count is full, the Mother of Numbers departs.
After birth, the original *yang* resides in the kidneys, from which true *qi* arises.
True *qi* nourishes the heart, from which true essence is generated—true essence returns to its source.
Ascending and descending in ceaseless cycles, if there is no loss or deficiency, longevity naturally follows.
If one knows the proper timing without error, and can draw and replenish with measure, eternal life may be attained.
If one perseveres in cultivation without weariness, and ceaselessly upholds the practice, when *yin* is exhausted and *yang* is pure, one may transcend the mundane and attain sainthood.

This is the profound principle of Heaven’s mechanism, an untransmitted secret of ancient times.
If you, my Lord, trust in this with unwavering resolve,
treating fame as a shackle and affection as an enemy,
avoiding illness as one would shun death itself—
then guard against losing your essence to foreign vessels,
and beware of dissipating your spirit among alien forms.
Hold fast to purity of mind, severing these roots at once,
so that the original *yang* does not stray nor the true *qi* scatter.
When *qi* flourishes and the *hún* has no *yin*,
when *yang* is strong and the *pò* contains *qi*,
each ascent and descent follows the model of Heaven and Earth,
each waxing and waning mirrors the movement of sun and moon.»

**Discourse on the Sun and Moon (Fourth Section)**

Lü said: *"I have a rough grasp of Heaven and Earth’s principles, but how do the sun and moon’s courses, conjunctions, and oppositions relate to humanity? I wish to hear your explanation."*

Zhōng replied: *"The Dao is formless yet gives birth to Heaven and Earth. The Dao is nameless yet moves the sun and moon. The sun and moon are the refined essences of Great Yin and Great Yang, silently marking the degrees of Heaven and Earth’s union, aiding in the generation of all things. Rising and setting east and west, they divide day and night; moving north and south, they regulate cold and heat. Day and night never cease, cold and heat spur one another, and within the *pò*, the *hún* arises, while within the *hún*, the *pò* takes form. Their advances and retreats adhere to the numbers of Heaven and Earth, their comings and goings follow measured degrees, never deviating from Heaven and Earth’s appointed times."*

Lü said: *"Why do the sun’s eastward rise and westward set divide day and night?"*

Zhōng replied: *"At the dawn of chaos, the primordial yellow defined its place. The form of Heaven and Earth resembles an egg; within the six extremes, it is round like a sphere. The sun and moon move above Heaven and below Earth, circling east and west, north and south, revolving like a wheel. The sun rises in the east and sets in the west; before it sets, it is day; after it sets and before it rises, it is night. Thus, the sun’s rising and setting divide day and night.

As for the moon, its rising and setting differ from the sun’s. It carries the *pò* in the west and receives the *hún* in the east, shining at night while the *hún* hides by day. Over accumulated days and hours, it sometimes rises, sometimes sets, moving from west to east. Initially, the *pò* within generates the *hún*—its form like a crescent bow at the first night, its light shining in the west. Next, the *pò* is half-filled with *hún*, corresponding to the upper crescent; at the first night, its light shines in the south. Then, the *pò* is fully filled with *hún*, opposing the sun; at the first night, its light shines in the east. Afterward, the *hún* within generates the *pò*—its form like a broken mirror at the first day, while the *hún* hides in the west. Next, the *hún* is half-filled with *pò*, corresponding to the lower crescent; at the first day, the *hún* hides in the south. Finally, the *hún* is fully filled with *pò*, opposing the sun; at the first day, the *hún* hides in the east. Thus, the moon’s rising and setting also divide day and night."*

「Lǚ asked: *"Why does the sun’s movement between south and north determine the cold and heat?"*

Zhōng replied: *"After the Winter Solstice, the sun rises at the very beginning of the *chén* hour (5:00–7:00 AM) at fifty percent, and sets at the very end of the *shēn* hour (3:00–5:00 PM) at fifty percent. Beyond this point, its rising and setting shift from south to north, reaching their peak at the Summer Solstice. After the Summer Solstice, the sun rises at the very end of the *yín* hour (3:00–5:00 AM) at fifty percent, and sets at the very beginning of the *xū* hour (5:00–7:00 PM) at fifty percent. Beyond this point, its rising and setting shift from north to south, reaching their peak at the Winter Solstice. When the sun moves from south to north, from the Winter Solstice to the Summer Solstice, it transforms cold into heat. When it moves from north to south, from the Summer Solstice to the Winter Solstice, it transforms heat into cold. The days of summer are the nights of winter, and the days of winter are the nights of summer. After the Winter Solstice, the moon rises from north to south, akin to the sun’s days. After the Summer Solstice, the moon rises from south to north, akin to the sun’s nights. Thus, the sun and moon’s reciprocal movements determine the cold and heat."*

Lǚ asked: *"The mechanisms of Heaven and Earth revolve in the rise and fall of yin and yang—how do these compare to human practice?"*

Zhōng replied: *"The mechanisms of Heaven and Earth lie in the rise and fall of yin and yang. Each rise and fall gives birth to the *Tàiji* (Supreme Polarity), nurturing and completing one another in an endless cycle. They never stray from the Dao, and thus endure forever. Those who cultivate the Dao—if they take Heaven and Earth as their model—can attain longevity and never die. If they emulate the sun and moon’s movements, their rising and setting, their conjunctions and separations, they reach the point where the moon absorbs the sun’s *hún* (essence), turning yang into yin. When yin is complete and yang is pure, the moon’s radiance becomes clear and bright, dispelling the dark *pò* (corporeal shadow) like the sun’s luminous splendor, illuminating all above and below. At this moment, it is as if a cultivator has refined their *qì* (vital energy) into *shén* (spirit), shed their physical form, and ascended to transcendence, achieving the essence of pure yang."*

Lǚ asked: *"For those who seek to cultivate the true Dao and serve the Way, when studying the principles of Heaven and Earth’s yin and yang rising and falling, as well as the sun and moon’s essence and their conjunctions, which should one prioritize?"*

Zhōng replied: *"First, one should follow the mechanisms of Heaven. By applying the principles of yin and yang’s rising and falling, true water and true fire are united into one. Refined into the Great Elixir, it eternally settles in the *dāntián* (elixir field), enduring calamities without perishing, and granting a lifespan equal to Heaven and Earth. If one grows weary of the dusty world, yet persists in cultivation, they should then harness the sun and moon’s conjunctions, refining yang to govern yin and preventing yin’s emergence. By nourishing the spirit with *qì*, they ensure the spirit does not scatter. With the five *qì* (vital energies) converging at the *yuán* (origin), the three *huā* (blossoms) gather at the crown—cutting off all worldly attachments and returning to the Three Isles (三島)."*

Lǚ said: *"Such profound and penetrating practices—what ails them is the lack of proper timing."*

Zhōng said:
*"The yin and yang rising and falling of Heaven and Earth—once a year they unite. The essence of the sun and moon flows back and forth, uniting once a month. The vital *qì* and fluids of humankind unite once in a day and night."*

From *Zhōng-Lǚ Chuándào Jí* (Discourse on Transmission of the Dao), *Lùn Sìshí* (On the Four Seasons), Fifth Chapter:

Lǚ said: *"The unions of Heaven and Earth, sun and moon—can one truly grasp the timing of years, months, days, and hours?"*

Zhōng replied:
*"There are four gradations of time. A human lifespan spans a hundred years: from one year to thirty is the time of youthful vigor, from thirty to sixty is the time of full maturity, from sixty to ninety is the time of old age, and from ninety to a hundred—or even a hundred and twenty—is the time of decline. This is the first gradation: the time within the body.

If one divides a day into twelve *chén* (double-hours), five *chén* as one *hòu* (watch), three *hòu* as one *qì* (phase), three *qì* as one *jié* (seasonal node), and two *jié* as one *shí* (season), then there are spring, summer, autumn, and winter. When it is spring, yin contains half-yang, and the *qì* shifts from cold to warmth—that is the time of spring. When it is summer, yang contains full yang, and the *qì* shifts from warmth to heat—that is the time of summer. When it is autumn, yang contains half-yin, and the *qì* shifts from heat to cool—that is the time of autumn. When it is winter, yin contains full yin, and the *qì* shifts from cool to cold—that is the time of winter. This is the second gradation: the time within the year.

If one takes the *lǚ* (sixth tone) rising from *lǘ* (fifth tone) and *lǘ* rising from *lǚ*, then in a month of thirty days, there are three hundred and sixty *chén*, three thousand *kè* (moments), and one hundred and eighty ten-thousandths. From the new moon to the first quarter, yin contains half-yang. From the first quarter to the full moon, yang contains full yang. From the full moon to the last quarter, yang contains half-yin. From the last quarter to the dark moon, yin contains full yin. This is the third gradation: the time within the month.

If one divides sixty *fēn* (minutes) as one *kè*, eight *kè* and twenty *fēn* as one *shí* (hour), and one *shí* and a half as one *guà* (trigram), then the *guà* determines the eight directions, and its correctness divides the four cardinal positions. From *zǐ* (11 PM–1 AM) to *mǎo* (5–7 AM), yin contains half-yang, and from *Tàimíng* (Great Brightness) arises *Shàoyáng* (Lesser Yang). From *mǎo* to *wǔ* (11 AM–1 PM), yang contains full yang, and pure *Shàoyáng* arises *Tàiyáng* (Greater Yang). From *wǔ* to *yǒu* (5–7 PM), yang contains half-yin, and from *Tàiyáng* arises *Shàoyīn* (Lesser Yin). From *yǒu* to *zǐ*, yin contains full yin, and pure *Shàoyīn* arises *Tàiyīn* (Greater Yin). This is the fourth gradation: the time within the day.

What is hard to obtain yet easy to lose is the time within the body; what departs swiftly yet returns slowly is the time within the year. Like lightning, swift as a falling stone is the time within the day. Days accumulate into months, months into years—years slip by, and time races forward. Chasing fame and profit while the restless mind remains unchecked, loving children and doting on grandchildren while affection still lingers. Even if one turns back to the Dao, how can one contend with aging and declining *qì*? Like spring snow or autumn flowers, only fleeting beauty remains; like evening sun or morning moon, no lasting light endures.

Those who follow the Dao find the time within the body hard to obtain. In the radiant sun and charming scenery, a hundred blossoms bloom fragrant. In pavilions by the water or towering halls, the cool breeze brings delight. Under moonlit nights in leisurely talk, or snow-filled days in shared drink—indulging in boundless pleasures, wasting limited time. Even if one turns back to the Dao, it must be when sickness binds them. Like a broken boat yet to cross, who would not seek rescue? Like a leaking roof needing repair, who would abandon hope of mending it? Those who follow the Dao have wasted their youthful years in vain.

Before the rooster crows, stepping out feels too late. When the street drums sound, returning home feels too early. Greed and delusion refuse to pause, vain thoughts fear no end. A hall filled with gold and jade—what use when sickness strikes? A single glance at grandchildren—who can replace the breath that fades? Day and night pass without cease, yet none awaken. Those who follow the Dao lament the time within the day.

Lǚ said: *"The time within the body, the time within the year, the time within the month, and the time within the day—all are time. Yet you, Master, say the time within the body is hard to obtain, and the time within the day is most regrettable. Why?"*

Zhōng replied:
*"Those who follow the Dao find youth hard to obtain. Cultivating in youth strengthens the primordial roots—all things are easily accomplished, and great success may be achieved in a thousand days. Those who follow the Dao also find middle age hard to obtain. Cultivating in middle age first completes what was lacking, then advances further. Initially, one reverses aging to return to youth, then enters the realm of transcending humanity. If one does not awaken in youth nor reflect in middle age, perhaps through calamity they turn to quietude, or through illness they aspire to the lofty. Cultivating in old age first addresses preservation, then speaks of nourishment. Then, through minor accomplishments, one accumulates *qì* until reaching middle attainment, and from middle attainment, one reverses aging to return to youth, refining the form to dwell in the world. Yet the five *qì* cannot converge at the *yuán* (origin), and the three yangs struggle to gather at the crown. Ascending as an immortal, transcending the physical—such fates are beyond reach. Thus, the time within the body is hard to obtain."*

吕问：“身中之时固知难得矣，而日中之时可惜者，何也？”
钟答：“人之一日如日月之一月，如天地之一年。大道生育天地，天地分位，上下相去八万四千里。冬至之后，地中阳升；凡一气十五日，上进七千里，计一百八十日。阳升至天，太极生阴。夏至之后，天中阴降；凡一气十五日，下进七千里，计一百八十日。阴降至地，太极复生阳。周而复始，运行不已，而不失于道，故能长久。运行日月，日月成形，周围各得八百四十里。月旦之后，六中起九：凡一日计十二时，魄中魂进七十里，凡十五日，计一百八十时，魄中魂进八百四十里。月望之后，九中起六：凡一日计十二时，魂中魄进七十里，凡十五日，计一百八十时，魂中魄进八百四十里。周而复始，运行不已，而不失于道，故能坚固。

大道长养万物，万物之中，最灵最贵者，人也。人之心肾，上下相远八寸四分，阴阳升降，与天地无二等。气中生液，液中生气，气液相生，与日月可同途。天地以乾坤相索，阴阳升降，一年一交合，不失于道，故一年之后有一年。日月以魂魄相生而精华往来，一月一交合，不失于道，故一月之后有一月。然人之交合，虽在一昼一夜，不知交会之时，又无采取之法。损时又不解补，益时又不解收；阴交时不解养阳，阳交时不解炼阴。月中不知损益，日中又无行持。过了一年无一年，过了一日无一日。当风卧湿，冒暑涉寒，不肯修持，而甘心受病，虚过时光，端坐候死。”

吕曰：“奉道之人，非不知年光虚度，岁月磋跎，而疾病缠身，死限将至。盖以修炼不知法，行持不知时，致阴阳交合有差，时月行持无准。”

钟曰：“身中用年，年中用月，月中用日，日中用时。盖以五脏之气，月上有盛衰，日上有进退，时上有交合。运行五度而气传六候。金、木、水、火、土，分列无差；东、西、南、北、中，生成有数。炼精生真气，炼气合阳神，炼神合大道。”

Lü said: *"When you speak of the Five Viscera’s *qi* as Metal, Wood, Water, Fire, and Earth, and of the Five Phases’ positions as East, South, West, North, and Center—how do they interact in mutual generation and completion, with their unions and adoptions occurring at specific times? How do they take and refine at appointed moments? I wish to hear your explanation."*

Zhōng replied: *"The Dao, having first differentiated to give birth to Heaven and Earth, Heaven and Earth having divided to establish the Five Sovereigns. The East is the Azure Sovereign, who governs the Spring season, and within the Yin, raises the Yang to make all things sprout. The South is the Vermilion Sovereign, who governs the Summer season, and within the Yang, generates the Yang to make all things flourish. The West is the White Sovereign, who governs the Autumn season, and within the Yang, raises the Yin to make all things mature. The North is the Dark Sovereign, who governs the Winter season, and within the Yin, advances the Yin to make all things wither. Each season comprises ninety days. Within each season, eighteen days belong to the Yellow Sovereign. In Spring, he assists the Azure Sovereign in generating growth; in Summer, he follows the Vermilion Sovereign in fostering maturation; in Autumn, he aids the White Sovereign in establishing completion; in Winter, he restrains the Dark Sovereign with stern authority. The Five Sovereigns govern in rotation, each presiding over seventy-two days, totaling three hundred sixty days for a year, assisting Heaven and Earth in adhering to the Dao.

The Azure Sovereign’s offspring are *Jiǎ-Yǐ*, *Jiǎ-Yǐ* of the East, the Wood phase. The Vermilion Sovereign’s offspring are *Bǐng-Dīng*, *Bǐng-Dīng* of the South, the Fire phase. The Yellow Sovereign’s offspring are *Wù-Jǐ*, *Wù-Jǐ* of the Center, the Earth phase. The White Sovereign’s offspring are *Gēng-Xīn*, *Gēng-Xīn* of the West, the Metal phase. The Dark Sovereign’s offspring are *Rén-Gǔi*, *Rén-Gǔi* of the North, the Water phase.

Manifested in the seasons as symbols, Wood is the Azure Dragon, Fire the Vermilion Bird, Earth the Hooked Array, Metal the White Tiger, and Water the Dark Tortoise. Manifested in the seasons as living things, when *Yǐ* and *Gēng* combine, in Spring there is the elm—green and white, not deviating from Metal and Wood’s hues. When *Xīn* and *Bǐng* combine, in Autumn there is the date—white and red, not deviating from Metal and Fire’s hues. When *Jǐ* and *Gēng* combine, at the end of Summer and beginning of Autumn, there is the melon—green and yellow, not deviating from Earth and Wood’s hues. When *Dīng* and *Rén* combine, in Summer there is the mulberry—red and black, not deviating from Water and Fire’s hues. When *Gǔi* and *Wù* combine, in Winter there is the tangerine—black and yellow, not deviating from Water and Earth’s hues.

By this analogy, the Five Sovereigns’ interactions, as they manifest in the seasons and give rise to living things, are innumerable."*

Lü said: *"If the Five Phases manifest in the seasons in this way, how do they manifest in the human body?"*

Zhōng replied: *"In humans, the head is round and the feet are square—mirroring the forms of Heaven and Earth. The rise and fall of yin and yang reflect the mechanisms of Heaven and Earth. The kidneys correspond to Water, the heart to Fire, the liver to Wood, the lungs to Metal, and the spleen to Earth. If we consider the Five Phases generating one another, then Water generates Wood, Wood generates Fire, Fire generates Earth, Earth generates Metal, and Metal generates Water. The generator is the mother; the generated is the child. If we consider the Five Phases restraining one another, then Water restrains Fire, Fire restrains Metal, Metal restrains Wood, Wood restrains Earth, and Earth restrains Water. The restrainer is the husband; the restrained is the wife.

In terms of mother-child relationships: the qi of the kidneys generates the qi of the liver, the qi of the liver generates the qi of the heart, the qi of the heart generates the qi of the spleen, the qi of the spleen generates the qi of the lungs, and the qi of the lungs generates the qi of the kidneys. In terms of husband-wife relationships: the qi of the kidneys restrains the qi of the heart, the qi of the heart restrains the qi of the lungs, the qi of the lungs restrains the qi of the liver, the qi of the liver restrains the qi of the spleen, and the qi of the spleen restrains the qi of the kidneys. The kidneys are the heart’s husband, the liver’s mother, the spleen’s wife, and the lungs’ child. The liver is the spleen’s husband, the heart’s mother, the lungs’ wife, and the kidneys’ child. The heart is the lungs’ husband, the spleen’s mother, the kidneys’ wife, and the liver’s child. The lungs are the liver’s husband, the kidneys’ mother, the heart’s wife, and the spleen’s child. The spleen is the kidneys’ husband, the lungs’ mother, the liver’s wife, and the heart’s child.

The heart’s manifestations within are the vessels; externally, they appear as complexion, with the tongue as its gateway. It is subdued by the kidneys and directed toward the lungs—this follows the logic of husband-wife. When it receives from the liver, it flourishes; when it encounters the spleen, it wanes—this follows the logic of mother-child. The kidneys’ manifestations within are the bones; externally, they appear as hair, with the ears as its gateway. It is subdued by the spleen and directed toward the heart—this follows the logic of husband-wife. When it receives from the lungs, it flourishes; when it encounters the liver, it wanes—this follows the logic of mother-child. The liver’s manifestations within are the sinews; externally, they appear as nails, with the eyes as its gateway. It is subdued by the lungs and directed toward the spleen—this follows the logic of husband-wife. When it encounters the kidneys, it flourishes; when it encounters the heart, it wanes—this follows the logic of mother-child. The lungs’ manifestations within are the skin; externally, they appear as fur, with the nostrils as its gateway. It is subdued by the heart and directed toward the liver—this follows the logic of husband-wife. When it receives from the spleen, it flourishes; when it encounters the kidneys, it wanes—this follows the logic of mother-child. The spleen’s manifestations within are the viscera, nourishing the heart, kidneys, liver, and lungs. Externally, they appear as flesh, with the lips and mouth as its gateway. Its inhalation and exhalation are regulated; it is subdued by the liver and directed toward the kidneys—this follows the logic of husband-wife. When it receives from the heart, it flourishes; when it encounters the lungs, it wanes—this follows the logic of mother-child. Thus, the Five Phases in the human body generate and restrain one another, transmitting qi as husband-wife and mother-child, revealing their waxing and waning here."*

Lü said: *"The heart is Fire—how does Fire descend? The kidneys are Water—how does Water ascend? The spleen is Earth. Earth, being central, supports Fire and yet inevitably restrains Water below. The lungs are Metal. Metal, being above, interfaces with Fire below and thus is diminished—how then can Water be generated? Those that generate are separated by intervals, while those that restrain are close and difficult to shift. How can these Five Phases, which inherently harm and restrain one another, be reconciled?"*

Zhōng replied: *"The Five Phases return to their origins, linked by a single qi. The primal yang ascends and refines true Water; true Water undergoes transformation and generates true qi; true qi undergoes transformation and generates the yang spirit. Initially, the Five Phases are positioned, establishing one husband and one wife. The kidneys are Water, yet Water contains Metal. Though Metal generates Water, when descending, one must recognize the Metal within Water. Water inherently resists Earth, so after gathering medicine, one must return Earth to Water.

The dragon is the liver’s symbol, the tiger the lungs’ form. The yang dragon emerges from the *Lí* mansion, the yin tiger arises from the *Kǎn* position. The Five Phases move in reverse. Qi is transmitted to the mother. From *Zǐ* to *Wǔ*, this is called ‘yang time generating yang’—the Five Phases invert, and fluids flow between husband and wife. From *Wǔ* to *Zǐ*, this is called ‘refining yang within yin.’ Yang cannot form without yin, and ultimately, without yin, there is no death. Yin cannot generate without yang, and ultimately, without yang, life is prolonged."*

Lü said: *"The Five Phases originate from the unity of yin and yang qi. What is meant by ‘one qi’?"*

Zhōng replied: *"This one qi—when father and mother unite, their essence and blood transform to form shape. The kidneys generate the spleen, the spleen generates the liver, the liver generates the lungs, the lungs generate the heart, the heart generates the small intestine, the small intestine generates the large intestine, the large intestine generates the gallbladder, the gallbladder generates the stomach, and the stomach generates the bladder. This is how yin, through essence and blood, transforms to form shape. Its yang remains at the origin of its initial generation—a single point of primal yang residing in the two kidneys.

Moreover, the kidneys are Water, yet Water contains Fire. This Fire ascends as qi, and through qi, it ascends to meet the heart. The heart is yang; combining yang with yang, the *Tàijí* generates yin, accumulating qi to produce fluids. The fluids descend from the heart and, through fluids, descend back to the kidneys. The liver is originally the heart’s mother and the kidneys’ child, transmitting the kidneys’ qi to the heart. The lungs are originally the heart’s wife and the kidneys’ mother, transmitting the heart’s fluids to the kidneys. Thus, the ascent and descent of qi and fluids mirror the yin and yang of Heaven and Earth."*

The liver and lungs transmit and conduct like the moon’s and sun’s reciprocal movement.

The Five Phases name this numerical principle.
Discussing their interplay and generation, it is the primal yang—one qi—as the foundation.
Within qi, fluids form; within fluids, qi arises.
The kidneys are the root of qi, the heart the source of fluids.

The numinous root is firm yet hazy and indistinct—within qi, true water spontaneously generates.
The heart’s source is pure yet dim and obscure—within fluids, true fire inherently resides.
Within fire, recognize the true Dragon; within water, discern the true Tiger.
When Dragon and Tiger intermingle, they transform into the Yellow Sprout.
When united at the Yellow Sprout, they coalesce into the Great Elixir—thus called *Jīndān*.
When the *Jīndān* is complete, it is called *Shénxiān*.

Lü said: *"When the *Jīndān* is perfected and the physical form is cast off to ascend as an immortal, returning to the Ten Directions, this is indeed known."*

How then is it called the Yellow Sprout?
Zhōng replied: *"The true Dragon and true Tiger are what it refers to."*

Lü said: *"What are the Dragon and Tiger?"*
Zhōng replied: *"The Dragon is not the liver—it is the yang Dragon, emerging from the true water within the *Lí* Palace.
The Tiger is not the lungs—it is the yin Tiger, arising from the true fire within the *Kǎn* position."*

**Discourse on Water and Fire, Section Seven**

Lü said: *"For one who seeks longevity, the refining of the Golden Elixir is the path. To refine the Golden Elixir, one must first obtain the Yellow Sprout. To obtain the Yellow Sprout, one must first secure the Dragon and Tiger. As they say, the true Dragon emerges from the *Lí* Palace, and the true Tiger arises from the *Kǎn* position. Within *Lí* and *Kǎn*, there is water and fire. But what do these water and fire refer to?"*

Zhōng replied: *"All within the body that is spoken of as water—such as the Four Seas, Five Lakes, Nine Rivers, Three Islands, the Hua Pool, Yao Pool, Phoenix Pool, Heavenly Pool, Royal Pool, Kun Pool, Yuan Pond, Lang Gardens, Divine Water, Golden Waves, Jade Dew, Jade Spring, Yang Ruxiao (lit. 'yang suet'), and White Snow—these are the names, and they cannot be fully enumerated. All within the body that is spoken of as fire are but the Sovereign Fire, Ministerial Fire, and Common Fire. These three fires take their root in the Original Yang, and from it arises the True Qi. When True Qi gathers, one attains peace; when True Qi weakens, one falls ill. If one dissipates True Qi and flees Original Yang, when Original Yang is exhausted and Pure Yang remains, the Original Spirit departs the body—then one is said to die."*

Lü said: *"Within the human body, from a single point of Original Yang, the three fires emerge. These three fires arise from the myriad waters and dense yin, easily dissipated yet difficult to ignite. When this yang is weak and yin is strong, fire is scarce and water is abundant, causing one to decline swiftly and fail to attain longevity. How then does one address this?"*

Zhōng replied: *"The Heart is the Sea of Blood, the Kidneys the Sea of Qi, the Brain the Sea of Marrow, and the Spleen-Stomach the Sea of Water and Grain—such are these Four Seas. The Five Viscera each possess their own fluids, governing their respective positions east, west, south, north, and center—such are these Five Lakes. The Small Intestine, twenty-four feet long and winding nine times above and below, is called the Nine Rivers; beneath it lies the Yuan Pond. The forehead is the Upper Island, the heart the Central Island, and the kidneys the Lower Island—within these Three Islands lie the roots and Lang Gardens. The Hua Pool lies beneath the Yellow Court, the Yao Pool emerges before the Elixir Gate, the Kun Pool ascends to meet the Jade Capital, the Heavenly Pool aligns with the Inner Palace, the Phoenix Pool is between the Heart and Lungs, and the Jade Pool lies within the lips and teeth. Divine Water is generated within the Qi, and Golden Waves descend from Heaven. Where the Vermilion Dragon resides, there are naturally Jade Dew and Jade Springs. Only after the fetal transformation is complete does one see White Snow and Yang Ruxiao. Nourishment has its seasons; when the flames are strong, one first calls it Jade Dew, then Golden Dew—both can restore the Elixir. Oil is added in measure, in response to bathing: first called Zhōng Tián (lit. 'Central Field'), then Xià Tián (lit. 'Lower Field')—both can refine the form. Jade Medicine and Golden Flowers transmute into the Yellow and White substances; the clarified butter and sweet dew are refined into wondrous fragrances.

Such are the functions of water. As for the Common Fire ascending to aid the Kidney-Qi in generating True Water; when Kidney-Water ascends to merge with Heart-Fluids and produce True Qi—then in its lesser application, it subdues demons and dispels illness, and in its greater, it refines the substance and ignites the Elixir. When the Microcosmic Orbit is employed, Fire rises to consume the body; when the Yang Barrier is constrained, one returns to the Original Elixir-Medicine. Distinguishing the Nine Regions’ influence nourishes the Yang-Spirit; burning the Three Corpses’ burdens dispels the Yin-Ghosts. Ascending, it strikes the Three Passes; descending, it erodes the Seven Souls. Refining the form into Qi enables flight as though weightless; refining Qi into Spirit allows shedding the body like a serpent’s molt. Such are the functions of Fire."*

「Lü said: *"At first, I heard the command: my concern was that Fire was too little and Water too much, making it easy to decline and decay. Next, I listened to lofty teachings, and realized that Water and Fire have such profound effects. Ultimately, how does one achieve transformation? How can the lesser overcome the greater, and the weak attain strength?"*

Zhōng said: *"When the Yin of the Two Eights is exhausted and the Yang of the Nine Threes flourishes, the Vermilion Elixir-Dan [金丹] will soon be formed, and through Seven Returns and Nine Refinements [七返九还], the Embryonic Immortal [胎仙] will transform itself. True Qi resides in the Heart, and the Heart is the source of Fluids. Original Yang [元阳] dwells in the Kidney, and the Kidney is the sea of Qi. The Bladder is the Common Fire [民火], but if it does not ascend to become the Celestial Fire [天机], it cannot be put to use, and the Bladder is also the repository of Fluids. If one fails to grasp the Celestial Mechanism [天机] or fathom the Mysterious Principles [玄理], practitioners of the Dao will struggle to achieve transformation and may not escape illness and death."*

Lü said: *"The transformation you speak of—whereby Yang flourishes, Yin is exhausted, and the Vermilion Elixir-Dan is formed, resulting in the Embryonic Immortal’s self-transmutation—how is this accomplished?"*

Zhōng said: *"The Heart and Kidney are separated by eight inches and four divisions, which reflects the fixed ratio of Heaven and Earth. The generation of Qi and Fluids from the Great Ultimate [气液太极] mirrors the union of Yin and Yang. The twelve hours of a day correspond to the twelve months of a year.

The Heart generates Fluids, not of its own accord, but because Lung-Fluids descend and Heart-Fluids flow. The Fluids move between the *husband* [夫] and *wife* [妇]—from above to below, returning to the lower fields—thus it is said: *the wife returns to the husband’s palace* [妇还夫宫].

The Kidney generates Qi, not of its own accord, but because Bladder-Qi ascends and Kidney-Qi flows. The Qi moves between the *parent* [父] and *child* [子]—from below to above, paying homage to the Central Original [朝中元]—thus it is said: *the husband returns to the wife’s chamber* [夫还妇室].

Liver-Qi guides and draws the Kidney-Qi upward, from below to above, until it reaches the Heart. The Heart is Fire; when the two Qi intermingle and steam in the Lung, the Lung-Fluids descend, and all Fluids originating from the Heart are called *Heart-generated Fluids* [心生液]. Since these Fluids are generated in the Heart and do not dissipate, they are called *True Fire* [真火].

The Lung-Fluids convey the Heart-Fluids downward, from above to below, until they reach the Kidney. The Kidney is Water; when the two Waters intermingle, they moisten the Bladder, and the Bladder-Qi ascends, all rising from the Kidney being called *Qi* [气]. Since this Qi is generated in the Kidney and does not wear away, it is also called *True Fire* [真火].

True Fire emerges from within Water—vague and indistinct, yet something exists within it. You cannot see it, nor can you grasp it.

True Water emerges from within Fire—deep and obscure, yet something vital exists within it. You may perceive it, but cannot retain it; you may retain it, but it will not stay."*

Lü said: *"The Kidney is Water, yet Qi arises from Water—this is called True Fire. What is the *thing* [物] within Fire? The Heart is Fire, yet Fluids arise from Fire—this is called True Water. What is the *vital essence* [精] within Water? If the *thing* within Water and the *vital essence* within Water have no discernible form, and even if you seek them, they are difficult to obtain—let alone their practical use—what are they for?"*

Zhōng said: *"The sages of antiquity, upon attaining the Dao, did not depart from these two *things*. Through their copulation, they cultivated the Yellow Sprout [黄芽], and with sufficient practice, they perfected the Embryo and formed the Great Elixir-Medicine [大药], becoming the True Dragon and True Tiger."*」

**Discourse on the Dragon and Tiger (Eighth Section)**

Lü said: *"The Dragon originates from the Liver’s form, the Tiger from the Lung’s shape. Within this Heart Fire, Fluids arise—these are True Water. Within Water, dim and obscure, the True Dragon hides. Though the Dragon is not of the Liver, how does it emerge from the *Li* mansion? Within this Kidney Water, Qi arises—this is True Fire. Within Fire, vague and indistinct, the True Tiger is concealed. Though the Tiger is not of the Lung, how does it issue from the *Kàn* position?"*

Zhōng said: *"The Dragon is a yang entity. It ascends and soars in Heaven, its cry summoning clouds, and with dew, it nourishes all things. In symbol, it is the Azure Dragon; in direction, *jiǎ-yǐ*; in element, Wood; in season, Spring; in the Dao, Benevolence; in the hexagram, *Zhèn*; within the five viscera of the body, it is the Liver. The Tiger is a yin entity. It races across Earth, its roar birthing wind, and with mountains, it commands all beasts. In symbol, it is the White Tiger; in direction, *gēng-xīn*; in element, Metal; in season, Autumn; in the Dao, Righteousness; in the hexagram, *Duì*; within the five viscera of the body, it is the Lung.

Now, the Liver is yang, yet it resides within a yin position. Thus, Kidney Qi transmits to Liver Qi—Qi flows from child to mother, generating Water from Water. When Kidney Qi is sufficient, Liver Qi arises, and once Liver Qi is born, it severs the Kidney’s residual yin, allowing pure yang Qi to ascend.

The Lung is yin, yet it dwells within a yang position. Thus, Heart Fluids transmit to Lung Fluids—Fluids circulate between husband and wife, with Fire overcoming Metal. When Heart Fluids arrive, Lung Fluids are born, and once Lung Fluids manifest, they sever the Heart’s residual yang, allowing pure yin Fluids to descend.

Because the Liver belongs to yang and severs the Kidney’s residual yin, when Qi passes through the Liver, it becomes pure yang. Within pure yang Qi, the True One Water is concealed—vague and formless—named the *yang Dragon*. Because the Lung belongs to yin and severs the Heart’s residual yang, when Fluids reach the Lung, they become pure yin. Within pure yin Fluids, the True yang Qi is borne—dim and unseen—named the *yin Tiger*.

Qi ascends, Fluids descend; originally, they cannot intermingle. Yet within Qi, the True One Water meets Fluids to unite, and within Fluids, the True yang Qi gathers with Qi of its own accord. If, during transmission, one adheres to the method, ensuring Kidney Qi does not stray—collecting the True One Water within Qi—and Heart Fluids do not dissipate—extracting the True yang Qi within Fluids—then child and mother meet, mutually cherishing, daily gaining the *Tài Mǐ*’s greatness.

A hundred days without flaw, the medicine’s power is complete. Three hundred days, the sacred embryo solidifies; three hundred days, the immortal fetus is perfected. Its form is like a pill, its hue like cinnabar and tangerine—named the *Dan-Yào*—eternally settled in the lower field. Retaining form in the world, enduring the great calamity and attaining longevity, these are the *land-bound celestial immortals."*

Lǚ said:
"The Kidney Water generates Qi, and within Qi lies the True One Water, named *Yīnhǔ* [the Yin Tiger], for the Tiger appears when meeting with Fluids. The Heart Fire generates Fluids, and within Fluids lies the True yang Qi, named *Yánglóng* [the yang Dragon], for the Dragon appears when merging with Qi. Things of like kind gather, and creatures group by nature—this is only right.

When Qi is generated, Fluids descend as well. Does the True One Water within Qi not follow the Fluids downward, transmitting itself to the Five Viscera? When Fluids are generated, Qi ascends. Does the True yang Qi within Fluids not follow Qi upward, emerging from the *Chónglóu* [Double Tower, i.e., the upper orifices]?

The True Water descends with the Fluids—how then can the Tiger mate with the Dragon? The True yang ascends with the Qi—how then can the Dragon mate with the Tiger? If the Dragon and Tiger do not mate, how can the *Huángyá* [Yellow Sprout, i.e., the embryonic Qi] arise? If the Yellow Sprout does not appear, how can the Great Medicine be formed?"

Zhōng said:
"Once Kidney Qi is generated, it is like the sun rising from the sea—mist and dew cannot obscure its radiance. The descending Fluids are like sparse and porous barriers—how can they overcome its Qi? When Qi is strong, the True One Water will naturally flourish.

Once Heart Fluids are generated, they are like the killing cold of winter—breath and exhortation cannot resist their chill. The ascending Qi is like a jade screen—how can it overcome the Fluids? When Fluids are abundant, the True yang Qi may be strong or weak—this cannot be determined."

Lǚ said:
"Qi and Fluids are generated at their own times. When the time for Qi arises, Qi prevails, and the True One Water also flourishes. When the time for Fluids arises, Fluids prevail, and the True yang Qi also flourishes. If the flourishing and decline are uncertain, why is that?"

Zhōng said:
"The kidney *qi* is easily dissipated and hard to preserve—this is the True Tiger. The heart Fluids are difficult to accumulate but easily lost—this is the True Dragon. Though the *Dan* scriptures number ten thousand volumes, their debates never stray beyond yin and yang. Yet within these two principles, all essence lies in the Dragon and Tiger. Among those who follow the Dao, only one or two in ten thousand truly grasp it. Some, through vast learning and memorization, may know the principles of Dragon and Tiger, yet fail to recognize their union or the method of refining them. Thus, sages past and present, though they devote their lives to cultivation, achieve only minor success. Generations pass with prolonged lifespans, yet none attain transcendence. Truly, it is because they cannot copulate the Dragon and Tiger, nor gather the Yellow Sprout to forge the elixir."

From *Zhōng-Lǚ Transmission of the Dao Collection*, *Discourse on the Elixir*, Chapter Nine:

Lǚ said:
"Since the principles of Dragon and Tiger are already known, may we then speak of the Golden Elixir and Great Medicine?"

Zhōng said:
"What is called *yào* [medicine] is that which cures disease. Diseases fall into three categories:

When exposed to wind, dampness, summer heat, or winter cold, when labor or rest is excessive, when hunger or satiety is untimely, or when one disregards natural order—this is called *huàn* [affliction], a disease of the seasons.

When one refuses cultivation, indulges in desires, dissipates primordial yang, and depletes true *qi*, growing gaunt with age—this is called *lǎo* [old age], a disease of time.

When *qi* is exhausted, the body hollowed, the soul dispersed, and the spirit spent, with a final sigh as the Four Great Elements dissolve—when the corpse lies abandoned in the wilderness—this is called *sǐ* [death], a disease of the body.

Now, seasonal afflictions follow the revolutions of spring, summer, autumn, and winter through cold, heat, warmth, and coolness. When yang is excessive and yin deficient, one treats with coolness. When yin is excessive and yang deficient, one treats with warmth. The elderly tend to cold, the young to heat; the obese to phlegm, the emaciated to stagnation. Men’s diseases arise from *qi*, women’s from blood. Replenish the deficient and reduce the excessive; preserve the weak and diminish the surplus. Minor cases may be treated with acupuncture and moxibustion; severe cases with medicinal decoctions. Though there are afflictions from disregard of natural order, and though seasonal diseases may be entrusted to wise physicians, who prescribe remedies to ensure recovery—how then does one treat the disease of old age? How does one cure the disease of death?"

The cleansing of the intestines and replenishing of the flesh—this was the skill of the ancient masters of medicine, whose wrinkled faces and white hair returned them to the appearance of youth, yet none could comprehend their methods.

The replacement of the skull and extension of limbs—this was the skill of the ancient masters of medicine, who preserved their forms and remained in the world to attain longevity, yet none could comprehend their methods.

Lü said: *"When the Dao is not followed in its proper order, diseases arise from the seasons; skilled physicians and fine medicines can indeed cure them. But how does one treat the ailment of failing years? How does one cure the suffering of exhausted *qi* and the end of life? Is there no medicine for these?"*

Zhōng said: *"All diseases have three degrees. Seasonal diseases are treated with medicines of grasses and woods, and they heal on their own. Diseases of the body, diseases of age—these are treated with medicines of two kinds: the first is called *inner elixir* (内丹), the second is called *outer elixir* (外丹)."*

Lü said: *"What is the *outer elixir*?"*

Zhōng said: *"In ancient times, the Highest Celestial Lord transmitted the Dao to the mortal realm, pointing and hinting at the principles of heaven and earth’s ascent and descent, the harmony of the sun and moon’s cycles. Since then, the elixir scriptures have spread throughout the world, and people have heard of the Great Dao.

The Master Guǎngchéng instructed the Yellow Emperor, and in his moments of governance, the Yellow Emperor followed the methods in accordance with the Dao. Though he persisted for long, he saw no effect.

The Master Guǎngchéng spoke of the true *qi* and true water between heart and kidney, the true yin and true yang between *qi* and water. When these are harmonized, they become the Great Medicine, comparable to gold and stone yet hidden as a treasure.

Thus, within the Kǒngtóng Mountains, he refined the Great Elixir through inner cultivation. In eight minerals, he used only cinnabar, from which he extracted mercury. Among five metals, he used only galena, from which he extracted silver. Mercury corresponds to the yang dragon, silver to the yin tiger. The heart’s fire is like the red of cinnabar, the kidney’s water like the black of galena. The annual fire follows its season, never failing the strategy of heaven and earth; the monthly fire is nurtured by oil, dividing the aptness of the civil and martial. He built a furnace of three tiers, each nine inches high, square outside and round within. He gathered the *qi* of the eight directions, responding to the signs of the four seasons. The shape of the golden cauldron, containing galena and mercury, is no different from the vital essence of the lungs. Sulfur serves as the medicine, combined with refined cinnabar, resembling the *huángpó* (黄婆)—three years for minor completion, taking it cures a hundred ailments. Six years for full completion, taking it extends one’s years. Nine years for great completion, taking it enables one to ascend and descend at will."*

The valiant man stretches his arms—
a span of ten thousand leagues.
Though he cannot return to Penglai,
he may yet escape the calamities of mortal life and live forever.

Lü said, *"Since ancient times, many have sought to refine the elixir, yet few have seen its fruits. Why is this?"*

Zhōng replied, *"Those who fail in elixir refinement fall into three categories:

First, they fail to distinguish true from false in their medicinal materials, or they do not master the timing of heating and cooling—thus, precious substances are wasted in smoke and flame, reduced to ash. They squander time and effort, achieving nothing.

Second, even if their materials are fine, they do not grasp the proper fire control. Or if they know the fire control, they lack the materials. These two failings, unaligned, yield no result.

Third, even if their materials are fine and the fire control is apt—never straying from the yearly, monthly, daily rhythms, with precise additions and subtractions, the *qi* full and the elixir complete—yet their external practices are incomplete. They transform into a *huángehè* (玄鹤) and soar into the sky, but without the means to take the elixir, their efforts are in vain.

Moreover, medicinal materials are the refined *qi* of heaven and earth condensed into form, while fire control is the technique of Daoist cultivation to attain the Way. In the age of the Three Sovereigns, the Yellow Emperor refined the elixir, requiring nine transformations to complete. In the age of the Five Emperors, the *Hunyuan* elixir took three years to perfect.

By the Warring States period, malevolent *qi* filled the void, corpses littered the fields, and living things could no longer absorb the refined *qi* of heaven and earth. Thus, medicinal materials grew scarce, and those who possessed the methods perished in exile or old age in the mountains and valleys. Even if elixir formulas and Daoist techniques were recorded on bamboo or silk, over time they decayed and were lost to the world.

If one claims medicinal materials exist in the mortal realm, then Qin Shǐhuáng would not have sought them in distant islands. If one claims elixir formulas exist in the mortal realm, then Wei Boyang would not have consulted the *Zhouyi* or relied on broad learning and rote memorization, only to mislead later generations—leading to ruined families and no success. To seek them externally is also a mistake."*

Lü said, *"The principles of external elixir refinement stem from Guangchéngzǐ. Following internal practices as its standard, even if one succeeds, it takes nine years to complete. And since medicinal materials are hard to obtain and formulas even harder, at best one may ascend—yet none have truly transcended mortality to return to the Ten Isles.

May I inquire about internal alchemy?"*

Lu said, *"External alchemy is not without use. Those who follow the Dao, awakening only in their later years, have roots that are not yet firmly established. The kidneys are the root of qi—without deep roots, the branches cannot flourish. The heart is the source of fluids—without pure waters, the flow cannot endure. One must rely on the Five Metals and Eight Stones, accumulating day after day, month after month, refining them into Three Grades. Each grade has Three Degrees, making Nine Grades in total. The Great Elixirs of Dragon and Tiger assist in nourishing the True Qi, refining the form so that one may dwell in the world with effortless lightness, ascending like flight. If one practices internal alchemy and understands the timing of union, knowing the methods of gathering—when the Embryonic Immortal is complete, one may achieve transcendence in days.

Those who do not awaken, clinging to external elixirs, burn with reckless fire, taking them with hopes of ascending to the celestial realms—how laughable! Since they fail to investigate the origins of external alchemy, I shall instead expound upon the principles of internal alchemy. The medicinal materials of internal alchemy arise from the heart and kidneys—these all people possess. The true elixir’s materials are inherently within Heaven and Earth, visible daily. The fire’s intensity follows the cycles of the sun and moon, and its cultivation mirrors the harmony of yin-yang union. When the Sacred Embryo is formed, True Qi is born. Within the Qi, there is Qi—like the Dragon nurturing its pearl."*

When the Great Elixir is complete, the Yang Spirit emerges, and there is a body beyond the body—like a cicada shedding its husk.

This internal elixir originates from the union of Dragon and Tiger, transforming into a yellow sprout. When the yellow sprout matures, lead and mercury are refined.

**From *Zhong Lü Transmission of the Dao Collection*, Treatise on Lead and Mercury (10):**
Lü said: *"The internal elixir does not depart from Dragon and Tiger. The Tiger emerges from the Kan palace—this is the water within Qi. The Dragon emerges from the Li palace—this is the Qi within water. External alchemy takes mercury from sand, likening it to the Yang Dragon. It uses silver from lead, likening it to the Yin Tiger. But if lead and mercury are external elixirs, how does the union of Dragon and Tiger produce the yellow sprout, which then refines into lead and mercury? What is meant by the lead and mercury within the internal elixir?"*

Zhong replied: *"The one that embraces the essence of Heavenly Unity and stands as the foremost of the five metals is black lead. Lead generates silver—lead is the mother of silver. Touched by the essence of the Great Yang, it becomes the foremost of all stones—this is cinnabar. Cinnabar generates mercury—mercury is the child of cinnabar. The difficult ones to obtain are silver from lead and mercury from cinnabar. If silver and mercury unite, through refining they naturally become the supreme treasure. This is the external logic of lead and mercury.

But speaking of internal matters, what is seen in humanity—ancient and modern debates differ greatly. Taking the profound and mysterious account: it originates from the moment of parental union, when essence and blood merge, enclosing True Qi, lodged in the mother’s pure Yin palace, with Spirit hidden before yin-yang differentiation. At three hundred days, the embryo is complete; at five thousand days, the Qi is full.

Speaking in terms of the Five Phases, the human body is fundamentally essence and blood—water precedes all. Speaking in terms of the Five Organs, essence and blood form the shape, with the kidneys first emerging. Within the kidney water lies concealed the initial parental True Qi of conception. This True Qi is hidden in the inner kidneys—this is what is called lead. The Qi generated by the kidneys, the True Unity water within Qi, is called True Tiger—this is the silver within lead.

Kidney Qi passes to Liver Qi, which passes to Heart Qi. Heart Qi, reaching the Great Polarity, generates fluids. Within the fluid is the Pure Yang Qi—this is cinnabar. Mercury is the Pure Yang Qi within the heart fluid. Qi and fluid accumulate into the fetal sac, transmitted within the Yellow Court. Fire is applied without error, and the Embryonic Immortal transforms naturally—this is when lead and silver merge with mercury, refined into treasure."

Lü said: *"Among the five metals, silver is taken from lead. Among the eight minerals, mercury is extracted from cinnabar. Placed in the crucible, combined with elixirs, mercury becomes cinnabar and silver becomes treasure. But in humanity, how does one extract silver from lead? How does one extract mercury from cinnabar? How does mercury become cinnabar? How does silver become treasure?"*

Zhong replied: *"Lead is the original True Qi of parents united into one, pure and inseparable. After forming, it is stored in the kidneys. The two kidneys face each other, ascending together as Qi—this is called Original Yang Qi. Within the Qi is True Unity water. Water ascends with Qi, and where Qi lingers, water lingers; where Qi scatters, water scatters. This water and Qi, like mother and child, never separate. The adept sees only Qi, not water.

If this True Unity water is united with the Pure Yang Qi of the heart, this is called the union of Dragon and Tiger, transforming into the yellow sprout. The yellow sprout is the Great Elixir—its material is fundamentally True Unity water as the embryo, internally containing Pure Yang Qi, just as the original parental True Qi, with essence and blood forming the fetal sac. Through the processes of transformation, at three hundred days the embryo is complete, Qi is full, and form and Spirit are perfected, separating from the mother.

After the outer form unites, union generates form. Those who follow the Dao—when kidney Qi unites with heart Qi, the Qi contains True Unity water bearing Pure Yang Qi, and Qi unites with water to form the fetal sac, resembling millet grains, nurtured without deficiency. Initially, Yin retains Yang; then, Yang refines Yin. Qi transforms into essence, essence into mercury, mercury into cinnabar, and cinnabar into Golden Elixir. When the Golden Elixir is complete, True Qi spontaneously arises, refining Qi into Spirit and achieving transcendence. The Fire Dragon departs from the murky world, riding the Dark Crane into Penglai Isle."*

Lü said: *"When form unites with form, form generates form. When Qi unites with Qi, Qi generates Qi—this cycle does not exceed three hundred days. After separation of form, how do the differing shapes of male and female resemble the colors of cinnabar and lead?"*

Zhong replied: *"When parental forms unite, the father’s essence enters first, followed by the mother’s blood, with blood enveloping essence to form the female. The female is internally Yang and externally Yin, symbolizing the mother—since blood is external. If the mother’s blood enters first, followed by the father’s essence, with essence enveloping blood to form the male, the male is internally Yin and externally Yang, symbolizing the father—since essence is external.

This blood originates from the heart and lacks Pure Yang Qi. This essence originates from the kidneys and contains Pure Yang Qi. Pure Yang Qi is the root of mercury—this is the True Unity water merging and entering the Yellow Court. Mercury is boiled with lead’s decoction, and lead is simmered with mercury’s fire. Lead without mercury cannot release True Unity water. Mercury without lead cannot transform into Pure Yang Qi."*
